nm.name: nanometer
nm.description: A unit of length equal to one billionth of a meter. Used in nanotechnology and physics.

um.name: micrometer
um.description: Also known as micron. Commonly used in biology and precision engineering.

mm.name: millimeter
mm.description: One thousandth of a meter. Frequently used in engineering and construction.

cm.name: centimeter
cm.description: One hundredth of a meter. Often used in everyday measurements and health (e.g., height).

dm.name: decimeter
dm.description: Rarely used unit equal to one tenth of a meter.

m.name: meter
m.description: The base unit of length in the International System of Units (SI).

dam.name: decameter
dam.description: A unit equal to ten meters. Rarely used.

hm.name: hectometer
hm.description: A unit equal to one hundred meters. Occasionally used for measuring distances.

km.name: kilometer
km.description: A unit of length equal to one thousand meters. Widely used in transportation and geography.

thou.name: thou
thou.description: Also known as a mil. Equal to one thousandth of an inch.

in.name: inch
in.description: A unit of length in the imperial system. Widely used in the United States.

ft.name: foot
ft.description: Equal to 12 inches. Common in architecture and everyday use in the U.S.

yd.name: yard
yd.description: Equal to 3 feet. Used in sports fields and U.S. land measurement.

mi.name: mile
mi.description: Used primarily for measuring distances in the U.S. and UK.

nmi.name: nautical mile
nmi.description: Used in air and sea navigation. Defined as exactly 1852 meters.

ftm.name: fathom
ftm.description: Used to measure depth in nautical contexts. Equal to 6 feet.

Mm.name: megameter
Mm.description: A unit equal to one million meters. Rarely used.

Gm.name: gigameter
Gm.description: A unit equal to one billion meters. Used in astronomy and planetary science.

au.name: astronomical unit
au.description: Average distance from Earth to the Sun. Used in space science.

ly.name: light-year
ly.description: Distance that light travels in one year. Common in astronomy.

pc.name: parsec
pc.description: Used in astronomy to express distances to stars and galaxies.

K.name: kelvin
K.description: Absolute temperature scale. 0 K = absolute zero.

C.name: degree Celsius
C.description: Common scale for daily use. 0°C = water freezing point.

F.name: degree Fahrenheit
F.description: Used primarily in the US. 32°F = water freezing point.

mm3.name: cubic millimeter
mm3.description: A metric unit of volume equal to a cube with 1 millimeter sides. Commonly used in small-scale measurements.

cm3.name: cubic centimeter
cm3.description: Equal to a cube with 1 centimeter sides. Often used in medicine and engineering.

mL.name: milliliter
mL.description: Equivalent to 1 cm³. Widely used in cooking and liquid measurements.

cc.name: cubic centimeter (alternate)
cc.description: Commonly used in medical and automotive contexts (e.g., engine displacement).

L.name: liter
L.description: A standard metric unit for volume. Used globally for liquids and gases.

dm3.name: cubic decimeter
dm3.description: Equal to 1 liter. Used in scientific and industrial contexts.

m3.name: cubic meter
m3.description: The base SI unit for volume. Used in construction, shipping, and large-scale measurements.

km3.name: cubic kilometer
km3.description: An enormous volume unit, used in geology or oceanography.

in3.name: cubic inch
in3.description: Common in engineering (e.g., engine displacement in the US).

ft3.name: cubic foot
ft3.description: Used in refrigeration, shipping, and construction in the US.

yd3.name: cubic yard
yd3.description: Common in construction (e.g., concrete or soil measurements).

gal_us.name: US gallon
gal_us.description: Standard liquid volume in the US (e.g., fuel efficiency).

gal_uk.name: UK gallon
gal_uk.description: Used in the UK and some Commonwealth countries.

qt_us.name: US quart
qt_us.description: A quarter of a US gallon. Common in cooking.

pt_us.name: US pint
pt_us.description: Half of a US quart. Used in beverages and recipes.

fl_oz_us.name: US fluid ounce
fl_oz_us.description: Used for liquids in nutrition labels and recipes.

fl_oz_uk.name: UK fluid ounce
fl_oz_uk.description: Slightly larger than the US fluid ounce (≈28.4 mL).

tbsp_us.name: US tablespoon
tbsp_us.description: Approx. 14.8 mL. Used in cooking and pharmaceuticals.

tsp_us.name: US teaspoon
tsp_us.description: Approx. 4.93 mL. Common in recipes and medicine.

bbl.name: barrel (petroleum)
bbl.description: Standard for oil volume (42 US gallons ≈ 159 L).

bu_us.name: US bushel
bu_us.description: Used in agriculture for dry goods (e.g., grains).

mg.name: milligram
mg.description: One thousandth of a gram. Commonly used in medicine and chemistry.

g.name: gram
g.description: Base unit of mass in the metric system (non-SI but accepted). Used in everyday measurements.

kg.name: kilogram
kg.description: The base SI unit of mass. Used globally in science, engineering, and commerce.

t.name: metric ton
t.description: Equal to 1,000 kilograms. Used in large-scale measurements like cargo or vehicles.

oz.name: ounce
oz.description: Common in cooking and postal services (≈28.35 grams).

lb.name: pound
lb.description: Widely used in the US for body weight and groceries (≈0.45 kg).

st.name: stone
st.description: Used primarily in the UK and Ireland for body weight (1 st = 14 lb).

gr.name: grain
gr.description: Historically used in archery and ammunition (≈64.8 mg).

cwt_us.name: US hundredweight
cwt_us.description: Equal to 100 lb (≈45.36 kg). Used in agriculture.

cwt_uk.name: UK hundredweight
cwt_uk.description: Equal to 112 lb (≈50.8 kg). Common in historical contexts.

slug.name: slug
slug.description: A unit of mass in gravitational systems (≈14.59 kg).

u.name: atomic mass unit
u.description: Used in physics and chemistry to express atomic and molecular masses.

Da.name: dalton
Da.description: Synonym for atomic mass unit (u). Common in biochemistry.

ton_short.name: short ton
ton_short.description: Equal to 2,000 lb (≈907 kg). Used in the US for industrial measurements.

ton_long.name: long ton
ton_long.description: Equal to 2,240 lb (≈1,016 kg). Common in UK shipping and mining.

mm2.name: square millimeter
mm2.description: Metric unit for very small areas, used in engineering and manufacturing.

cm2.name: square centimeter
cm2.description: Commonly used for small surface measurements (e.g., paper size).

m2.name: square meter
m2.description: Base SI unit of area. Used in construction, real estate, and science.

km2.name: square kilometer
km2.description: Used for large-scale measurements like cities or countries.

ha.name: hectare
ha.description: Equal to 10,000 m². Common in agriculture and land measurement.

in2.name: square inch
in2.description: Used in manufacturing and screen sizes (≈6.45 cm²).

ft2.name: square foot
ft2.description: Standard unit for real estate and flooring in the US (≈0.093 m²).

yd2.name: square yard
yd2.description: Used in textiles and landscaping (≈0.84 m²).

mi2.name: square mile
mi2.description: Large area unit for cities or natural reserves (≈2.59 km²).

ac.name: acre
ac.description: Traditional land measurement unit (≈4,047 m² or 0.4 ha).

are.name: are
are.description: Equal to 100 m². Rarely used outside historical contexts.

hectare.name: hectare
hectare.description: Standard unit for land area (equal to 100 ares or 2.47 acres).

barn.name: barn
barn.description: Extremely small unit used in nuclear physics to measure cross-sections.

tsubo.name: tsubo
tsubo.description: Traditional Japanese unit for room/land area (≈3.3 m²).

tatami.name: tatami
tatami.description: Based on traditional Japanese mat size (varies regionally).

fanega.name: fanega
fanega.description: Traditional Spanish land measurement (≈6,430 m² or 0.64 ha).

ns.name: nanosecond
ns.description: One billionth of a second. Used in computing and physics for precise timing measurements.

μs.name: microsecond
μs.description: One millionth of a second. Common in electronics and light measurements.

ms.name: millisecond
ms.description: One thousandth of a second. Used in sports timing and audio processing.

s.name: second
s.description: The base unit of time in the International System of Units (SI).

min.name: minute
min.description: 60 seconds. Standard unit for everyday time measurement.

h.name: hour
h.description: 60 minutes or 3,600 seconds. Fundamental unit for timekeeping.

d.name: day
d.description: 24 hours or 86,400 seconds. Based on Earth's rotation period.

week.name: week
week.description: 7 days or 604,800 seconds. Standard calendar unit.

month_avg.name: average month
month_avg.description: Approximately 30.44 days. Used for statistical calculations.

year_common.name: common year
year_common.description: 365 days or 31,536,000 seconds. Non-leap calendar year.

year_avg.name: average year
year_avg.description: Mean tropical year (365.2422 days). Used in astronomical calculations.

julian_year.name: Julian year
julian_year.description: Exactly 365.25 days (31,557,600 seconds). Used in astronomy.

sidereal_day.name: sidereal day
sidereal_day.description: Earth's rotation period relative to stars (≈23h 56m 4.1s).

sidereal_year.name: sidereal year
sidereal_year.description: Earth's orbital period relative to stars (≈365.256 days).

kyr.name: kiloyear
kyr.description: 1,000 years (31.5576 gigaseconds). Used in geology and archaeology.

Myr.name: megayear
Myr.description: One million years (31.5576 teraseconds). Geological time unit.

Gyr.name: gigayear
Gyr.description: One billion years (31.5576 petaseconds). Cosmological time scale.

fortnight.name: fortnight
fortnight.description: 14 days or 1,209,600 seconds. Common in British usage.

planck_time.name: Planck time
planck_time.description: The smallest meaningful unit of time in quantum mechanics.

shake.name: shake
shake.description: 10 nanoseconds. Used in nuclear chain reaction timing.

jiffy_physics.name: jiffy (physics)
jiffy_physics.description: The time for light to travel one fermi (≈3 × 10⁻²⁴ s).

m/s.name: meter per second
m/s.description: SI base unit of speed. Used in scientific and engineering contexts.

km/h.name: kilometer per hour
km/h.description: Common speed unit for transportation (1 km/h ≈ 0.621 mph).

mph.name: mile per hour
mph.description: Standard speed unit in the US (1 mph ≈ 1.609 km/h).

knot.name: knot
knot.description: Nautical mile per hour. Used in maritime and aviation navigation.

c.name: speed of light
c.description: Fundamental physical constant (299,792,458 m/s in vacuum).

Pa.name: pascal
Pa.description: SI unit of pressure (1 N/m²). Used in meteorology and engineering.

kPa.name: kilopascal
kPa.description: Common for tire pressures and medical devices (1 kPa = 0.145 psi).

bar.name: bar
bar.description: Used in meteorology and scuba diving (1 bar ≈ 0.987 atm).

atm.name: standard atmosphere
atm.description: Earth's atmospheric pressure at sea level (101.325 kPa).

psi.name: pound per square inch
psi.description: Widely used in engineering (1 psi ≈ 6.895 kPa).

mmHg.name: millimeter of mercury
mmHg.description: Blood pressure measurement unit (1 mmHg ≈ 1 Torr).

J.name: joule
J.description: SI unit of energy (1 N·m). Fundamental in physics.

kJ.name: kilojoule
kJ.description: Common in nutrition labels and chemistry (1 kJ ≈ 0.239 kcal).

cal.name: calorie
cal.description: Energy to heat 1g of water by 1°C (1 cal = 4.184 J).

kcal.name: kilocalorie
kcal.description: Food energy unit (1 kcal = 1 Cal = 4.184 kJ).

eV.name: electronvolt
eV.description: Energy gained by an electron in 1V potential (1 eV ≈ 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ J).

W.name: watt
W.description: SI unit of power (1 J/s). Used for all energy transfer rates.

kW.name: kilowatt
kW.description: Common for engine and appliance ratings (1 kW ≈ 1.341 hp).

bit.name: bit
bit.description: Basic unit of digital information (8 bits = 1 byte).

KB.name: kilobyte (decimal)
KB.description: Storage marketing unit (1000 bytes). Differs from KiB (1024 bytes).

MB.name: megabyte (decimal)
MB.description: Common file size unit (1 MB = 1,000,000 bytes). Used for storage devices.

GB.name: gigabyte (decimal)
GB.description: Storage capacity standard (1 GB = 1 billion bytes). Example: HDDs, SSDs.

TB.name: terabyte (decimal)
TB.description: Large-scale storage (1 TB = 10¹² bytes ≈ 1000 GB). Used for cloud storage.

KiB.name: kibibyte
KiB.description: Actual OS measurement (1 KiB = 1024 bytes). Windows incorrectly calls this 'KB'.

MiB.name: mebibyte
MiB.description: Real memory unit (1 MiB = 1024 KiB). Used by Linux/macOS for accuracy.

GiB.name: gibibyte
GiB.description: Actual RAM/storage unit (1 GiB = 1024 MiB). Often mislabeled as 'GB'.

TiB.name: tebibyte
TiB.description: Precise large-scale unit (1 TiB = 1024 GiB ≈ 1.1 TB). Used in filesystems.

PB.name: petabyte (decimal)
PB.description: Enterprise/Big Data (1 PB = 10¹⁵ bytes). Example: Data center capacity.

EB.name: exabyte (decimal)
EB.description: Global data scale (1 EB = 10¹⁸ bytes). Example: Annual internet traffic.

ZB.name: zettabyte (decimal)
ZB.description: Future data volumes (1 ZB = 10²¹ bytes). Theoretical for now.

YB.name: yottabyte (decimal)
YB.description: Extreme-scale data (1 YB = 10²⁴ bytes). Currently hypothetical.

mol.name: mole
mol.description: SI base unit for amount of substance (6.022×10²³ entities).

M.name: molar
M.description: 1 mole per liter. Standard concentration unit.

uM.name: micromolar
uM.description: Used for dilute solutions (1 μM = 10⁻⁶ M).

mol/m3.name: mole per cubic meter
mol/m3.description: SI unit for amount concentration (1000 mol/m³ = 1 M).

A.name: ampere
A.description: SI base unit of electric current.

uA.name: microampere
uA.description: Used for small currents (1 μA = 10⁻⁶ A).

V.name: volt
V.description: SI derived unit of electric potential.

O.name: ohm
O.description: SI derived unit of electrical resistance.

Bq.name: becquerel
Bq.description: SI unit of radioactivity (1 decay per second).

Gy.name: gray
Gy.description: SI unit of absorbed dose (1 J/kg).

Sv.name: sievert
Sv.description: SI unit of equivalent dose (biological impact).
